Explanation: The thyroid is supplied by the superior thyroid artery, the inferior thyroid artery, and in some people by a third artery supplying the centre of the gland (referred to as the "thyroid ima artery" when present. The superior thyroid artery branches off from the external carotid artery, and the inferior thyroid artery branches off from the thyrocervical trunk, which itself is a very short branch off of the right subclavian artery.

An "X" test for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is positive in 60 out of 100 patients with a known diagnosis of SLE and is normal in 80 out of 100 controls. If the "X" test is positive in a person chosen at random from this population of 200 individuals analyzed, what is the percent probability that this person has SLE?
Notes:
D

Of the population of 200:

100 have SLE
60 have SLE and test positive
40 have SLE and test negative
80 do not ,have SLE and test negative
20 do not ,have SLE and test positive

Therefore, 80 test positive, of which 20 have SLE and 60 do not.

Therefore, 20/80 = 75%

This extra peice of detail describes ,H. influenzae.

In 1997 in an Italian city there were 2100 live births and 100 stillbirths (&gt,20 weeks of gestation). Five newborns died in the first 28 days of life, 11 died in the first year of life. There were 25 twins and 3 triplets. Two mothers died. What was the perinatal mortality of this city?
Notes:
D

Generally:
'perinatal mortality' includes stillbirths (varies, death at ~20 weeks gestation until just before birth) and neonates (death after birth up until 28 weeks of age)
'infant mortality' includes neonates (died after birth but before 28 weeks of age) and infants (died between 28 weeks of age and 1 year).

In 1997 in an Italian city there were 2100 live births and 100 stillbirths (&gt, 20 weeks of gestation) Five newborns died in the first 28 days of life, 11 died in the first year of life. There were 25 twin and 3 triplets. Two mothers died. What was the infant mortality in this city?
Notes:
E

Infant mortality ->, death of a child after birth, before 1 year of age.

Stillbirths don't count, so don't add them ->, 2100 total births.

Newborns included ->, 11 + 5 = 16.

Death of mothers, twins and triplets it irrelevant information.

therefore 16/2100.

A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency room with severe respiratory distress. Small amounts of pulmonary oedematic fluid are removed with suction.

The patient is placed in mechanical ventilation with an FIO2 of 0,5 and the arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) shows a PO2 of 160 mmHg and a PCO2 of 40 mmHg. Which of the following would be your alveolar partial pressure of oxygen?
Notes:
C

Requires alveolar gas equation.



FIO2 = fraction of inspired gas that is oxygen = 0,5 in this case.
PATM is always 760 mmHg
PH20 is the saturated vapour pressure of water at body temperature (37¬∫C) and atmospheric pressure. It is always 47 mmHg.
PaCO2 is the arterial partial pressure of CO2 ,and is given in the question in the results of the arterial blood gas analysis (ABG)

0,5 * (760 - 47) - (40/0,8) = 306,5 mmHg

760 and 47 are constants. So focus on:

FIO2 * 713 - (PaCO2 / 0,8)

***

n.b. RER generally falls in the range 0,5 to 1. Regardless of which RER is used, closest answer will be 300 mmHg in this scenario.

Frage: The figure opposite shows the static pressure-volume curve of a patient's lung (solid line). The dashed line indicates the pressure-volume curve of a normal person. What is approximately the patient's lung compliance in the 1-9L volume range?

A patient is having severe postoperative pain and needs a loading dose of analgesic to feel better as soon as possible. The drug we have chosen has the following pharmacokinetic properties: Half-life = 12 hours, Clearance = 0.08L / min, Volume of distribution = 60L. The serum concentration we would like to try to achieve is 8 mcg/ml. Which of the following comes close to the loading dose to give them?
Notes:
D

\(Loading \space dose = \frac {C_p \times V_d}{FS}\)

Where
\(C_p\) is desired peak concentration
\(V_d\) is volume of distribution
\(F\) is bioavailability
and \(S\) is the fraction of drug in salt form (?) which is active drug

\(\frac {8 \times 60}{1}\)

***

This question does not specifiy route of administration. I assume it is intended to be intravenous, which means a bioavailability of 1 and therefore a perfect match for D using the formula (8 times 60).

The increased bone resorption indicates that either

Therefore, high calcium and phosphate from the bone resorption, high PTH as the body fails to bring calcium into line.

Frage: An agitated 20-year-old university student is taken to the ER shortly after ingesting a bottle of aspirin. Which arterial blood gas (ABG) result is most likely to be associated with this scenario?
Notes:
B

Normal values:
  • pH (7.35-7.45)
  • PaO2 (75-100 mmHg)
  • PaCO2 (35-45 mmHg)
  • HCO3 (22-26 meq/L)
  • Base excess/deficit (-4 to +2)
  • SaO2 (95-100%)
A: low pH, low PaO2, low PaCO2
B: low pH, low PaO2, high PaCO2
C: normal pH, low PaO2, high PaCO2
D: normal pH, normal PaO2, normal PaCO2
E: high pH, lower border PaO2, low PaCO2

ABG Components: ,
  • pH = ,measured ,acid-base balance of the blood
  • PaO2 = ,measured the ,partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood
  • PaCO2 = ,measured ,the ,partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood
  • HCO3 = ,calculated ,concentration of bicarbonate in arterial blood
  • Base excess/deficit = ,calculated ,relative excess or deficit of base in arterial blood
  • SaO2 = ,calculated ,arterial oxygen saturation unless a co-oximetry is ,obtained, in which case it is ,measured

Frage: Which result of the blood gas analysis to which it is most likely associated. A morbidly obese 49-year-old man being evaluated for an ideal surgical bypass.
Notes:
C

In morbid obesity ABG would be more likely to show normal pH, low oxygen (hypooxemia), and high CO2 (hypercapnia). This is "obesity hypoventilation syndrome".

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4444067/
"Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is defined as a combination of Obesity (BMI>,40 kg/m2), daytime hypoventilation characterized by hypercapnia and hypoxemia (PaCO2 >, 45 mm Hg and PaO2 <, 70 mm Hg at sea level)..."
"Three hundred and thirty patients met the inclusion criteria for hypoventilation based on arterial blood gas PCO2 >, or equal to 45 mmHg, normal PH and elevated serum bicarbonate."

Normal values:
  • pH (7.35-7.45)
  • PaO2 (75-100 mmHg)
  • PaCO2 (35-45 mmHg)
  • HCO3 (22-26 meq/L)
  • Base excess/deficit (-4 to +2)
  • SaO2 (95-100%)
A: low pH, low PaO2, low PaCO2
B: low pH, low PaO2, high PaCO2
C: normal pH, low PaO2, high PaCO2
D: normal pH, normal PaO2, normal PaCO2
E: high pH, lower border PaO2, low PaCO2

Frage: A patient with a bacterial infection needs intravenous antibiotic therapy. The chosen drug has a clearance (Cl) of 70ml / min. The volume distribution (Vd) is 50L. The schedule is to administer the drug every 6 hours and reach a blood level of 4mgl / L. It is not intended to administer a loading dose. Which of the following maintenance doses should be given to reach the indicated blood level?
Notes:
C


For an intravenously administered drug, the bioavailability ,F ,will equal 1, since the drug is directly introduced to the bloodstream.

1) Convert clearance to correct units (ml/min to L/h) factor for conversion is 0,06.

70ml/min * 0,06 ml/min = 4,2 L/h

4mg/L is our desired peak concentration.

2) 4,2 * 4 = 16,8 mg/h

3) 16,8 * 6 = 100,8

4) 100mg is the closest option

Volume of distribution is mentioned in this question to mislead. Volume of distribution is required to calculate bioavailability when the administered drug is not intravenous.

Frage: Which of the following statements is true about vaccinations in pregnant women?
Wahl_A: Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication to the hepatitis B vaccine
Wahl_B: Pregnant women who have not completed the first series of tetanus-diphtheria (Td) should start soon after delivery
Wahl_C: Women who present themselves after the first trimester of pregnancy during the flu period should be vaccinated routinely
Wahl_D: Women who receive rubella vaccination within 4 weeks of the onset of pregnancy should be advised of the high risk of having a baby with congenital rubella
Wahl_E: Women who test negative for rubella at their first antenatal visit should routinely receive a rubella vaccination during the second trimester of pregnancy
Antwort: Women who receive rubella vaccination within 4 weeks of the onset of pregnancy should be advised of the high risk of having a baby with congenital rubella
Notes:
D

A - No, the Hep B vaccine is recommended in some cases even for pregnant women.
B - No, tetanus-diphtheria vaccines should be administered if otherwise indicated. Pregnancy is not contraindication, no need to wait until after delivery.
C - No, women who are or will be pregnant during influenza season should receive the influenza vaccine. Stage of the pregnancy does not matter.
D - This is true - but is worth noting that the MMR vaccine should not be given to pregnant women or women attempting to get pregnant under any circumstances. This point about counselling is relevant in scenarios where a woman has accidentally been administered the MMR.
E - No, pregnant women should never receive the MMR.
